column1: 18369853;Soup or Sonic;"Introduction: The usual chase starts for a few seconds until it stops for the  Latin names: Ultra-sonicus Ad Infinitum and Nemesis Ridiculii
column2: plus a ""bonus"" name for the Road Runner's beep: Beepius-beepius. The chase then moves around mountain corners until it ends on a mountainside
column3: with the Road Runner ducking behind a corner and leaving a cloud of dust for the coyote to run into. Wile E. rides the dust cloud all the way through the air
column4: and finally stops to determine where he is
column5: a question mark appearing over his head. He opens a ""door"" in the cloud only to see that he is in midair
column6: and sheepishly closes the door as the cloud disperses
column7: and then changes his question mark of surprise to an exclamation point before the inexorable pull of gravity takes effect. 1. The pair pull up onto opposite outcroppings

column11: he keeps falling back to the bottom of it. Eventually
column12: the pole turns around so fast that it whirs like a propeller
column13: and then grinds against a cliffside all the way down to the part Wile E. is holding. When it finally stops rotating
column14: the coyote then pulls himself onto the narrow bar left of the pole and accepts his fate. 2. In a gag that sees four attempts in this cartoon
column15: Wile E. sits on a rocket and lights the fuse
column16: aiming towards the Road Runner on the opposite site of the chasm.  The first attempt fails when the fuel and nosecone launch out of the rocket
column17: leaving Wile E. sitting on an empty hull. The hull crunches down
column18: and then Wile falls
column19: annoyed
column20: to the canyon floor. 3. As the Road Runner burns rubber on the ground roads
column21: Wile E. is pulling back on a falling safe attached to a rope and pulley. Eventually
column22: however
column23: the weight overcomes him and the coyote is pulled through the pulley
column24: removing all of his chest fur
column25: and then down onto a see-saw as the safe lands next to him. Wile then slides off the rock face to fall into the canyon a fourth time
column26: and is then smashed by the safe
column27: leaving the coyote's torso thin and flat. 4. The second attempt at the rocket is foiled when the rocket falls out of its aim towards the Road Runner and points directly downwards before it fires
column28: leading to an extra-speedy fifth fall. 5. Now
column29: Ross animates a sequence in which Wile E. sticks a firecracker into the center hole of a Frisbee  and throws it at his nemesis
column30: but before he releases the disc
column31: the firecracker drops out of the hole and sizzles at Wile E's foot. The coyote doesn't notice until he puts his foot down on the firework and instinctively pulls it away just before it explodes
column32: leaving him dazed but apparently unhurt. Wile then walks away like Charlie Chaplin
column33: revealing behind him that his tail is on fire
column34: unknown to him until he passes the horizon and he yelps in pain! 6. On his third attempt with the rocket
column35: he lights the fuse but it burns quickly and fires successfully out from under him before he could get ready and leaves Wile floating in midair with a cloud of dust blocking his view below. Unable to see what is below him
column36: Wile pokes his foot through the cloud and consequently suffers gravity for the sixth time
column37: as he holds up a sign stating ""GOODBYE"" and then flipping to ""AGAIN"".  7. To get the bird to stick
column38: Wile leaves out a sheet of ACME Giant Fly Paper in the road and sits down on a rock

column40: assumes the Road Runner has been caught
column41: and leaps out to catch him
column42: but instead of the Road Runner
column43: he has caught an actual giant fly. The fly is very unhappy about being stuck on the paper and thus wraps the coyote with it
column44: who tiptoes away from the scene. 8. On his final attempt at the skyrocket

column47: this causes him to return to the rocket and to light the fuse with his tail

column49: the rocket is off target

column51: who allows the coyote to be humiliated privately. The rocket finally explodes

column55: and the coyote is eager to try them at work. As luck would have it

column1: 529276;Jaws: The Revenge;" On the island of Amity
column2: sheriff Martin Brody
column3: the hero of previous shark attacks
column4: has died from a heart attack. His wife
column5: Ellen Brody
column6: thinks it was from fear of the shark. She now lives with their son Sean  and his fiancee Tiffany . Sean works as a police deputy and is sent to clear a log from a buoy a few days before Christmas. As he does so
column7: a massive great white shark bursts out of the water
column8: rips off his arm
column9: and then pulls him under the surface and kills him
column10: sinking his boat in the process. Ellen is convinced that the shark targeted Sean on purpose. She decides to go to the Bahamas to spend time with her older son Michael
column11: his wife Carla ([[Karen Young
column12: and their five-year-old daughter Thea . There
column13: Ellen meets carefree airplane pilot Hoagie . Michael – along with partners Jake
column14: William
column15: and Clarence – work as marine biologists. At one point
column16: the shark that killed Sean unexpectedly appears and attempts ""devouring"" their boat but fails. The crew decides to keep quiet about the shark's presence due to Ellen's attempts of convincing Michael to find a job on land. Ellen becomes so obsessive that she starts having nightmares of being attacked by a shark. Then she starts getting psychic feelings when the shark attacks Michael. She and the shark seem to share a strange connection that is unexplained. The crew decides to attach a device to the shark that would track its heartbeat. Using chum to attract the beast
column17: Jake stabs the device's tracking pole into the beast's side. The next day
column18: Michael is chased by the shark and barely manages to escape unharmed
column19: and soon enough
column20: Thea goes on an inflatable banana boat with her friend Margaret and her mother. During Carla Brody's speech about her sculpture ... the shark suddenly attacks
column21: kills Margaret's mother and scares Thea. Ellen Brody is horrified by the event and
column22: to end the farce
column23: goes on Jake's boat. She intends to sacrifice herself to stop the killing. Michael soon returns home and lets the truth slip about the shark
column24: which doesn't turn out well. Michael and Jake are eventually flown by Hoagie to look for Ellen and they find her and the shark in pursuit of her boat. Hoagie lands the plane on the water
column25: ordering Michael and Jake swim to the boat as the shark drags the plane and Hoagie underwater. Michael was upset with Ellen for putting herself in danger
column26: and Ellen apologized for worrying him. Much to Ellen Brody's disbelief
column27: Hoagie survives. Jake and Michael hastily put together an explosive powered by electrical impulses. Michael and Jake go back up on deck and begin blasting the shark with the impulses
column28: which begin to drive the shark mad. As Jake moves to the front of the boat
column29: the shark is absent until it unexpectedly lunges out from the water
column30: giving it the chance to pull Jake under and maul him
column31: although he manages to get the explosive into the shark's mouth before he is dragged under and attacked. Michael continues to blast the shark with the impulses
column32: causing it to rise out of the water again
column33: igniting the bomb right as Ellen thrusts the broken bowsprit into its stomach. The shark explodes upon impact and the front of the ship sinks to the bottom of the sea with the creature's corpse. Michael then hears Jake
column34: severely injured but alive
column35: floating in the water
column36: and the four survive the harsh encounter and make it back to land. The film concludes as Hoagie flies Ellen back to Amity Island."

column1: 20631892;Sagar alias Jackie;Sagar Alias Jacky  is a gangster who is known for solving problems among big gangs. The Chief Minister's son-in-law
column2: Manu is kidnapped and the police are unable to find a clue. Manu's wife Indu realises that the police have been influenced by her brother Hari who seems to know the kidnappers. Indu decides to call her best friend Sagar to help find her husband. Sagar calls his best henchmen from all over Kerala for the job. The gang then travels to Goa where Sagar's contact tells him that the kidnappers are the Rosario brothers who run the most powerful gang in the Goa underworld. After considerable difficulties
column3: Sagar and his gang locate the night club where Manu is held hostage and helps him to escape. This audacity does not sit well with the Rosarios who swear vengeance against Sagar. They kidnap one of Sagar's favourite gangsters and demand ransom. Sagar responds by kidnapping two of the three Rosario brothers and demands that his man be released at once. Realising that they would never be able to defeat Sagar in a heads-on battle
column4: the Rosario brothers make a deal with Manu and Hari to deliver Sagar's current location. The Rosarios then try to assassinate Sagar but fail. Frustrated with repeated defeats
column5: the Rosarios then approach Sagar's rival
column6: Nanthakrishna Naina([[Suman . Naina supplies them with a sniper
column7: Sheikh Imran
column8: who is also an internationally infamous assassin. Imran is asked to assassinate Manu so that the Sagar can be framed for the murder. But the Rosarios' plan backfires as Indu gives witness that Sagar was not responsible for her husband's murder. Imran is then asked to assassinate Sagar. He manages to kill Sagar's bodyguard but Sagar himself escapes. Sagar then hunts him down and kills him. The Rosarios then kidnap Sagar's love interest Arati
column9: a news reporter. Sagar is asked to come to a place to work out a deal. When he reaches there
column10: he finds Arati dead. Enraged
column11: Sagar goes to the Rosarios' club and goes on a killing spree. Then he goes to Dubai where Naina is hiding on a yacht. With the help of some gangsters he plants explosives on the yacht and blows it up. The film ends when Sagar informs Indu that her husband has been avenged.

column1: 24577134;The Healer;"Ralph Bellamy is ""The Healer""  in this 1930s morally uplifting pot-boiler. Bellamy is a doctor that has come home to a warm springs to try to heal children from the unnamed crippling disease . He runs a destitute camp for these children
column2: assisted by Evelyn  who looks upon the Doc as a great man. Mickey Rooney is Jimmy
column3: a paraplegic kid whom the Doc promises to cure. This little triangle is interrupted by rich girl Joan who cons the good Doc into building a sanitorium for the wealthy with her father's money. Doc is momentarily swayed
column4: but comes to his senses just as a forest fire threatens his original cabins around the warm spring. His treatment of Jimmy pays off as Jimmy rides a bicycle to save the day. Doc realizes that his true love is Evelyn
column5: not the self-interested Joan."

column2: Positive;"Rachel
column3: a high school girl
column4: seems to have the life that most people envy: she has a steady boyfriend
column5: great friends
column6: and a place on the school's soccer team. Preparing for college and separating from her boyfriend are the main worries of this teen

column1: 35779717;Geometria;"A Mexican widow  receives a letter from the high school attended by her son . It informs her that the boy is about to fail his geometry exams for the third time. The woman berates her son
column2: then turns on the television
column3: refusing to speak to him. The boy leaves the room
column4: vowing that he will never fail geometry again. The boy resorts to using black magic in order to pass the exam. In a dark room
column5: he reads from a tome of sorcery
column6: which states
column7: ""As a protection for the invocation of a major demon
column8: place yourself inside a pentagon drawn with your own blood. This pentagon will be your only protection."" The boy proceeds to follow these instructions. While the woman sits in the living room
column9: watching a pastiche of The Exorcist
column10: she hears her son screaming from the next room. When she enters
column11: she finds him standing in the middle of the bloody seal. He shouts a warning
column12: telling her that the pentagon is his only protection. A glowing portal opens in the wall
column13: and a demon  steps through. The boy asks the demon to grant two wishes. The first is that he will not fail geometry again. The second is the return of his father
column14: Francisco
column15: who died in an accident three months ago. The demon complies with the latter
column16: causing Francisco to materialise immediately. However
column17: he is now a mindless zombie. Francisco kills and eats his wife
column18: while their son looks on in horror
column19: unable to step out of the pentagon for fear of losing its magical protection. The demon commands the boy to surrender
column20: but he refuses to give in
column21: saying that he cannot be harmed while he stands within the pentagon. The demon reasons that he has already granted one of the boy's two wishes: his family is together again. He also points out that what the boy has drawn is not a pentagon
column22: but a hexagon
column23: which offers no magical protection whatsoever. The demon muses that the boy's other wish has also been granted: he will never fail geometry again. Francisco approaches his son from behind and takes hold of his head
column24: tilting it backwards. The boy laments the unfairness of his situation. The demon agrees
column25: and reaches out a hand to take hold of his throat. The screen fades to black as ripping sounds are heard. {{quote box}}"

column1: 23299845;In the Land of the Deaf;"This film focuses on the interrelationships between Deaf culture and language in France. Its overview encompasses a broad range of perspectives
column2: costrasting the stories of a family who has been deaf and thriving for five generations with the story of a woman whose deafness was misunderstood
column3: causing her to be confined for a time in an asylum for the insane. The documentary features hearing-impaired people of all ages and from all walks of life. With their profound deafness in common
column4: the children and adults featured in this film communicate their dreams and thoughts through sign language. In one segment
column5: Philibert focuses his camera on group of schoolchildren who are learning how to communicate in a world where they must read lips and speak words.Nickel
column6: Mark. ""Brown to offer French Film Festival at Cable Car Cinema Feb. 10-20
column7: Brown University News Service. February 7
column8: 2000. The personal lives of some of the pupils and various adults are explored
column9: including an actor
column10: a sign-language teacher
column11: and an engaged couple.Harvard Film Archive Cinematheque: In the Land of the Deaf."

column1: 226664;About Schmidt;Warren Schmidt is retiring from his position as an actuary with Woodmen of the World
column2: an insurance company in Omaha
column3: Nebraska. Schmidt is given a retirement dinner that seems to bring no comfort. Schmidt finds it hard to adjust to his new life outside of work
column4: feeling useless. One evening
column5: he sees a television advertisement about a foster program for African children
column6: Plan USA
column7: and decides to sponsor a child. He soon receives an information package with a photo of his foster child
column8: a small Tanzanian boy named Ndugu Umbo
column9: to whom he relates his life in a series of candid
column10: rambling letters. Schmidt visits his young successor to offer his help
column11: but the offer is politely declined. As he leaves the building
column12: Schmidt sees the contents and files of his office
column13: the sum of his entire career
column14: set out for garbage collectors. He describes to Ndugu his longtime alienation from Helen
column15: his wife
column16: who suddenly dies from a blood clot in her brain just after his retirement and their purchase of a Winnebago Adventurer motor home. Friends arrive
column17: along with Jeannie
column18: his only daughter
column19: and her fiancé Randall Hertzel from Denver. They console him at the funeral
column20: but Jeannie later berates him for taking his wife for granted
column21: such as by refusing to fully pay for the Winnebago  and burying her in a cheap casket. He asks her to move back for a while to take care of him
column22: but she refuses. Meanwhile
column23: Randall tries to entice him into a pyramid scheme. Schmidt feels that Randall
column24: a waterbed salesman
column25: is unsuited to his daughter
column26: who he feels could do better. After the couple leaves
column27: Schmidt is overcome by loneliness. He stops showering
column28: sleeps in front of the television
column29: and goes shopping with a coat over pajamas to load up on frozen foods. In his wife's closet he discovers some hidden love letters disclosing her long-ago affair with a mutual friend. Schmidt angrily confronts the friend
column30: cursing the betrayal. In order to find some control in his life
column31: he decides to take a journey alone in his new Winnebago to see his daughter and convince her not to marry Randall. He tells Jeannie he's headed out early to the wedding
column32: but she makes it clear she doesn't want him there until right before the ceremony. Schmidt visits places from his past
column33: including his hometown and college campus. His childhood home has been replaced by a tire shop. While at a trailer campground
column34: he is a dinner guest of a friendly and sympathetic couple. Schmidt makes at pass at the wife
column35: and flees in terror when she adamantly rejects his advance. Schmidt later forgives the late Helen for the affair and apologizes to her for his own failings as a husband. Feeling full of purpose after forgiving his wife
column36: Schmidt arrives in Denver with the intent of stopping Jeannie's wedding. He stays at the home of Roberta
column37: Randall's mother. He meets Randall's socially odd
column38: off-putting family and tries unsuccessfully to dissuade Jeannie from the marriage. Schmidt throws out his back after sleeping on Randall's waterbed
column39: infuriating Jeannie. Schmidt later flees to his Winnebago after Roberta makes a pass at him in a hot tub. The next day
column40: Schmidt
column41: under the influence of oxycodone
column42: attends the wedding and delivers a kind speech at the dinner
column43: hiding his disapproval. Before leaving Denver
column44: Schmidt composes a letter to Ndugu. Schmidt questions what he has accomplished in life
column45: lamented that he will soon be dead
column46: that his life has made no difference to anyone
column47: and that eventually it will be as if he has never existed at all. A pile of mail is waiting for him at home. Schmidt opens a letter from Tanzania. It is from a nun
column48: who writes that Ndugu is illiterate but appreciates Schmidt's letters and financial support very much. A painting drawn by Ndugu is enclosed
column49: showing two smiling stick figures
column50: one large and one small

column1: 27403920;Oil for the Lamps of China;"Ambitious
column2: idealistic Stephen Chase  goes to work for the Atlantis Oil Company and is sent to a remote outpost in rural China run by ""No. 1 Boss"" . After a while

column8: only to have him die on the voyage. As they become better acquainted
column9: Stephen comes up with an idea (partly to save himself from losing [[Face . He asks Hester to marry him

column12: No. 1 Boss
column13: is callously transferred to a lesser position
column14: the old man commits suicide rather than accept the insult. The new boss

column21: but he is so contemptuous of the Chinese that two important clients refuse to renew their contracts unless he is fired. Stephen is torn

column24: earning the best record of any branch in China. Then
column25: communists take over the city. An officer  shows up at the company's offices and demands the gold stored in the safe. Stephen bargains with him and gets everyone except McCarger and himself evacuated to a ship by promising to give up the gold in a few hours. In the meantime

column27: a very well-connected Chinese customer and good friend
column28: hoping he can use his influence. When Ho bravely shows up however

column30: Stephen and McCarger take the gold and escape out the back door. McCarger is killed and Stephen wounded

column33: when his boss outlines his plan to institute modern business practices
column34: Stephen disagrees
column35: explaining that
column36: despite appearances

column39: he is given only menial tasks in an effort to get him to quit . Hester gives Stephen's boss a tongue lashing and reveals that her husband holds the patent for a lamp the company uses to popularize the use of its product. However

column1: 2524925;The Land Before Time III: The Time of the Great Giving;"Littlefoot and his friends are constantly being bullied and browbeaten by three teenage dinosaurs: Hyp

It is implied during the discussion thereof that Hyp's own experience of harsh treatment by his father is the cause of his harshness toward others after he bullies Littlefoot and the others and leads the argument of Cera's father and Littlefoot's grandfather with Cera's dad calling Littlefoot a bad influence enraging Grandpa which he causes

column31: Littlefoot's grandfather

column35: the dinosaurs survive the time until the plants start to grow again by feeding on the last remains of the plants
column36: moving from one verdant area to another and sharing everything they find; a behavior which gives this time its name “The Time of the Great Giving”."

column1: 657446;Liar Liar;"In Los Angeles
column2: California Fletcher Reede  is a career-focused lawyer and divorced father. He loves spending time with his young son Max ([[Justin Cooper ; they often play a game where Fletcher makes his hand into ""the Claw"" and pretends to chase Max with it. But Fletcher has a habit of giving precedence to his job
column3: breaking promises to Max and his ex-wife Audrey
column4: and then lying about the reasons. Fletcher's compulsive lying has also built him a reputation as one of the best defense lawyers in the state of California as he is climbing the ladder in the firm for which he works. Ultimately
column5: Fletcher misses his son's fifth birthday party because he is having sex with his boss Miranda
column6: in the hopes of making partner. Max makes a birthday wish that his father would be unable to tell a lie for an entire day — a wish that immediately becomes true. Fletcher soon discovers
column7: through a series of embarrassing incidents — such as when he tells Miranda that he has ""had better"" sex than he just did with her — that he is unable to lie
column8: mislead
column9: or even withhold a true answer. These incidents are inconvenient
column10: as he is fighting a divorce case in court which
column11: should he win
column12: could be a huge boost to his career. His client is the self-centered
column13: money grabbing Samantha Cole . His main witness is willing to commit perjury to win
column14: but Fletcher discovers that he cannot even ask a question if he knows the answer will be a lie; during the case he even objects to himself when he tries to lie to get the desired information. Meanwhile
column15: Audrey is planning to move to Boston with her new boyfriend Jerry
column16: and decides that Max is going with them so that she can protect him from getting hurt by Fletcher. Fletcher tries desperately to delay the case
column17: even beating himself up
column18: but he cannot conceal that he is able to continue
column19: so the judge  insists that he does. Finally he realizes that his client had lied about her age and therefore had signed her prenuptial agreement while a minor
column20: rendering it invalid. This allows him to win his case truthfully
column21: but the repercussions become a catalyst to his understanding of what he himself is about to lose. Samantha who only cared about her ex-husband's money
column22: takes custody of her children purely so her ex-husband would be forced to continue paying her for child care and literally pulls the children out of the arms of their responsible and caring father. Fletcher then has a crisis of conscience and shouts at the judge to reverse the decision
column23: and is taken to jail for contempt of court. Audrey refuses to pay his bail
column24: which is eventually paid by his secretary Greta
column25: who forgives him for his earlier rude truth-tellings after hearing he ""went all noble"" in front of their firm's senior partner. Now recognizing his son Max as his highest priority
column26: Fletcher struggles to keep him. He hurries to the airport
column27: but Audrey and Max's plane has already left the terminal. Desperate
column28: he hijacks a mobile stairway and pursues the plane onto the runway. The plane finally stops
column29: but Fletcher is injured. On his way to the hospital
column30: he vows to his son to spend more time with him and never hurt him again. Even though the 24 hours of truth are up
column31: Max knows he means it
column32: and Audrey decides not to move to Boston with Jerry after all. One year later
column33: Fletcher and Audrey are celebrating Max's birthday. The lights go off when Max blows out his birthday candles. When they go back on
column34: Fletcher and Audrey are kissing. Fletcher asks Max if he wished for his mom and his dad to get back together and Max replies ""No
column35: I wished for roller blades!"" The family seemingly returns to normal as Fletcher chases Audrey and Max around the house with ""the Claw""."

column1: 1591973;Hush… Hush
column2: Sweet Charlotte;"In 1927
column3: young belle Charlotte Hollis  and her married lover

column6: Louisiana. However

column11: leading most to presume that she is the murderer. The story jumps to 1964. Charlotte is now a wealthy spinster

column13: believing his daughter guilty. Charlotte has believed all these years that her father killed Mayhew
column14: but everyone else assumes that it was Charlotte

column17: refusing to leave. She keeps the foreman
column18: his demolition crew
column19: and the bulldozer away by shooting at them with a rifle. They temporarily give up and leave. Charlotte is living with her housekeeper
column20: Velma
column21: in the Hollis mansion. Seeking help in her fight against the Highway Commission
column22: she calls upon Miriam
column23: a poor cousin who lived with the family as a girl. Miriam renews her relationship with Drew Bayliss
column24: a local doctor who jilted her after the murder. Charlotte's sanity deteriorates with Miriam's arrival
column25: her nights haunted by a mysterious harpsichord playing the song Mayhew wrote for her and by the appearance of Mayhew's disembodied hand and head. Velma
column26: suspecting that Miriam and Drew are after Charlotte's money
column27: seeks help from Mr. Willis
column28: an insurance investigator who is still interested in the Mayhew case and who has visited Mayhew's ailing widow
column29: Jewel . Miriam fires Velma
column30: who later returns and discovers that Charlotte is being drugged. Miriam sees the housekeeper trying to take Charlotte out of the house. The two argue at the top of the stairs. Velma tries to escape
column31: but knowing Velma has discovered the drugs
column32: Miriam smashes a chair over her head. Velma falls down the stairs to her death. One night
column33: a drugged Charlotte runs downstairs in the grip of a hallucination
column34: believing John has returned to her. Miriam and Drew decide to trick Charlotte into shooting Drew with a gun loaded with blanks
column35: after which Miriam helps dispose of the ""body"" in a swamp. Charlotte returns to the house and sees the supposedly dead Drew at the top of the stairs
column36: reducing her to whimpering insanity. Now believing Charlotte completely mad and secure in her room
column37: Miriam and Drew go into the garden to discuss their plan: to drive Charlotte insane in order to get her money. Miriam also tells Drew that back in 1927 she saw Jewel murder her husband. She's been using this knowledge to blackmail Jewel for all these years
column38: while plotting to gain possession of Charlotte's wealth. Charlotte overhears all. She moves toward a huge stone urn on the ledge of the balcony
column39: almost directly over the lovers' heads. Miriam embraces Drew
column40: then the two look up and into Charlotte's knowing eyes. They are paralyzed by the sight as Charlotte tips the stone urn off the ledge
column41: crushing them both to death. The next morning

column1: 11685571;The Emperor Jones;"The film is based rather loosely on the play
column2: adds an entire backstory before O'Neill's actual play begins
column3: and includes several new characters that do not appear in it . Some people consider the movie to be just a vehicle for showing off Robeson's musical talent . However
column4: the film does provide what may be Robeson's greatest dramatic performance in a movie
column5: considered by many to be worthy of an Oscar nomination that it did not receive. In the film version
column6: the opening shots are of an African ritual dance. Some critics are quick to assess the opening as representative of the ""primitive"" black world to which Brutus Jones will eventually revert. However
column7: more scholarly-based reviews of the film understand the complexities of the allusion to and comparison between the roots of the African American church and the rhythmic chanting often seen in African religious practices. A quick dissolve takes us into a Baptist church in the American South
column8: where the dancing of the congregation presents an image that argues for a continuity between the ""savage"" Africans and the ring-shout Baptists. Such suggestive editing may be the kind of element that causes viewers to suspect the film of racism. Similarly
column9: the film makes copious use of the word ""nigger""
column10: as did O'Neill's original play. African Americans criticized O'Neill's language at the time
column11: so its preservation and expansion in the film present another cause for critique. Given Robeson's subsequent career as a Civil Rights activist
column12: the spectacle of his character using the term so frequently in regard to other blacks seems shocking today. As for the plot
column13: Brutus Jones has just been hired as a Pullman Porter
column14: a job that served the upward mobility of thousands of African American men in the first half of the twentieth-century. Jones proudly shows off his uniform to his girlfriend Dolly
column15: setting up the contrast with the later scenes in which ""the Emperor Jones"" parades around in overdone military garb. But Jones is quickly corrupted by the lures of the big city
column16: taking up with fast women and gamblers. One boisterous crap game leads to a fight in which he inadvertently stabs Jeff
column17: the man who had introduced him to the fast-life and from whom he had stolen the affections of the beautiful Undine . A stint on the chain gang allows the film its first opportunity to show Robeson without his shirt on
column18: an exposure of male nudity unusual for 1933 and certainly for a black actor. Here and later the director plays on Robeson's sexual power and
column19: implicitly
column20: on cultural stereotypes about the libidinal power of black men. Jones escapes the convict's life after striking a white guard who was torturing and beating another prisoner. Making his way home
column21: he briefly receives the assistance of his wife before taking a job stoking coal on a steamer headed for the Caribbean. One day
column22: he catches sight of a remote island and jumps ship
column23: swimming to the island. The island is under the crude rule of a top-hatted black despot who receives merchandise from Smithers
column24: the dilapidated white colonial merchant who is the sole Caucasian on the island. Jones rises to become Smithers' partner and eventually ""Emperor"". He dethrones his predecessor with a trick that allows him to survive what appears to be a fusillade of bullets
column25: creating the myth that he can only be slain by a silver one. Jones's rule of the island involves increasing taxes on the poor natives and pocketing the proceeds. The highlight is a twenty-five minute spoken monologue taken directly from O'Neill's play
column26: in which Brutus Jones
column27: hunted by natives in revolt
column28: flees through the jungle and slowly disintegrates psychologically
column29: becoming a shrieking hysteric who runs right into the path of his pursuers."

column1: 4039635;First on the Moon;"A group of journalists are investigating a highly secret document when they uncover a sensational story: that even before the Second World War
column3: the first rocket was made in the USSR and Soviet scientists were planning to send an orbiter to the moon and back. The evidence is convincing; it is clear that in this case
column4: Soviet cosmonauts were first. The movie follows the selection and training of a small group of cosmonauts. The one who shines above the others  is Captain Ivan Sergeyevich Kharlamov . He is helped into a space suit and loaded into the capsule
column5: and the rocket lifts off for the Moon—but contact with it is soon lost. Most of the remainder of the film seems to follow the search for information about what happened next
column6: as the 1930s space program appears to have dissolved immediately after
column7: with no reason given . It is implied that Kharlamov returned to Earth
column8: but with no fanfare and apparently no assistance from the space program. A number of men are shown as suspected of being Kharlamov—the NKVD seems to be conducting a criminal investigation of the program and it is implied that those involved
column9: including Kharlamov himself
column10: are in hiding. It seems that the capsule returned to Earth and landed in Chile
column11: and that Kharlamov journeyed to the Soviet Far East by way of Polynesia and China
column12: yet feared capture on his return. His wife apparently covered for him when interrogated as to his whereabouts. The narrator never ties the story together coherently
column13: however; the interviews and footage are shown without supporting commentary
column14: in a narration style reminiscent of an actual documentary of the Soviet lunar program
column15: The Red Stuff.http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/282742/The-Red-Stuff-The-True-Story-of-the-Russian-Race-for-Space/overview The very end of the movie shows the only footage of the mission itself after launch
column16: explaining it as a film which was found at the Chilean landing site and is currently in the possession of ""the Natural museum in the town of Antafagasta"". First there is a brief clip showing Kharlamov piloting the vehicle
column17: presumably on final approach to the Moon. Following that is an equally brief panorama of a lunar landscape with the capsule or lander  resting on the surface
column18: apparently taken by Kharlamov during lunar EVA. Both scenes are shown as stills on the movie's cover. Then there is a short clip of the other cosmonauts walking through a hangar with the 1930s space program director
column19: and the credits roll."

column1: 14582951;A Game for Vultures;"It is the late 1970s
column2: and smuggler David Swansey  specialises in importing goods to war-torn Southern Rhodesia
column3: defying international sanctions imposed on the doomed nation. Swansey is eventually contracted by the Ian Smith administration to arrange an illicit purchase of American-made Iroquois helicopters for counter-insurgency operations against black African nationalists. However
column4: word of his plan soon reaches the latter
column5: who apply strong political pressure to kill the deal in its cradle - the aircraft shipment in question is impounded upon reaching neighbouring South-West Africa. Meanwhile
column6: one of the many indigenous guerillas resisting the white supremacist policies of the Rhodesian regime is Gideon Marunga
column7: veteran combatant and reluctant participant in atrocities directed against unarmed civilians by his fellow insurgents. Marunga discovers that Swansey
column8: with the aid of the Rhodesian Security Forces and South African sympathizers
column9: hopes to lead an armed raid on the airfield where the Iroquois are being temporarily held - with the intention of stealing them across the border into Rhodesia. On the day of the assault
column10: Marunga arrives at the airfield and stalls the attacking troopers
column11: while his accomplices succeed in destroying some of the helicopters. In the firefight which ensues he comes face to face with Swansey
column12: and the two men subsequently share a weary moment of reflection on their stalemate. Both abruptly part ways; the smuggler permits his enemy to escape unarmed into the night. As word of the foiled transaction spreads
column13: Swansey finds himself unable to continue conducting business on the global scale and is restricted to Rhodesia
column14: where he faces conscription into active duty with the armed forces. The film's storyline closes as Marunga and Swansey confront each other on the battlefield again - this time through the sights of their rifles."

column1: 25094002;Rose by Any Other Name...;The story follows the main characters Rose a comfortably out woman who identifies as lesbian and Anthony a decent progressive straight man who serendipitously meet and then unexpectedly find themselves falling for each other. Rose has to navigate the reaction of her friends  and her family  while Anthony too has to deal with his friends who are equally nonplussed.

column1: 6575053;Deepstar Six;"The crew of a deep ocean station ""DeepStar Six""
column2: which is funded by the Navy
column3: is expected to perform scientific studies as well as install an underwater missile silo. While checking on the area they are to build the silo
column4: they discover an underwater cave created by magma. The cave is supposedly millions of years old. Their marine biologist
column5: Dr. Scarpelli  wants to study the cave
column6: but Dr. Van Gelder does not wish to jeopardize the DeepStar project and wants to destroy the cave instead. After Osborne  and Hodges  blast the cave open
column7: they send in an unmanned vehicle
column8: which is mysteriously lost; they search for the pod in a small submarine when they are attacked by a mysterious creature. Joyce Collins  loses contact and tells Snyder  to get help
column9: but before he can the station is attacked by the same creature and begins to slowly flood and gradually slide towards a nearby chasm. Captain Laidlaw  and McBride  try to rescue them
column10: but are attacked by the same creature. Only McBride and Joyce escape; Laidlaw's spine is crushed
column11: so he stays behind and commits suicide by flooding the station. After four deaths and the functional loss of the station
column12: their command gives the green light to abandon the site. They first must secure the missiles
column13: though; since Cpt. Laidlaw is dead
column14: Snyder is ordered to follow procedures based on preset computer instructions. Because the creature was ""very aggressive"" Snyder reports the cause as ""aggression""  so the computer orders the missiles be detonated. Snyder follows the orders without question. The resulting shockwave damages the station and they are forced to abandon it . They first must decompress before heading to the surface. Unfortunately
column15: the decompression chamber was also damaged. The crew figures out a way to maintain pressure so they can safely leave
column16: but while Richardson is sent to repair external damage he is again attacked by the sea creature
column17: a huge reptilian/crustacean with crab claws and a reptilian tail. Richardson manages to get back into the airlock but almost immediately water gushes in
column18: followed by the creature
column19: who rips Richardson in half. Scarpelli
column20: in shock over his death
column21: is attacked next while the remaining crew head to higher ground to arm themselves. Snyder gets a harpoon gun while the rest of the crew use shotguns. They have to complete repairs to the station in order to leave and so they re-enter the flooded area and throw lights to distract the creature . When the creature emerges from the water
column22: Van Gelder inadvertently backs into Snyder's weapon and is punctured with a carbon dioxide charge
column23: which explodes. Snyder becomes mentally unstable as his guilt has made him erratic. He panics when he hallucinates a dead Van Gelder coming at him. Dr. Norris gives him something to calm his nerves
column24: but it is not enough; he has a complete breakdown and comandeers the one emergency escape pod. Snyder heads to the surface without adjusting to the pressure; he ""explodes"" during his rapid ascent. Meanwhile Dr. Norris
column25: McBride
column26: and Joyce are stuck so McBride risks swimming to the mini-sub in complete darkness and silence
column27: to use it as an escaping pod. The creature attacks Dr. Norris and Collins
column28: cornering them. Joyce manages to escape to the decompression chamber; Dr. Norris distracts the creature and tells Joyce to leave. Dr. Norris then holds live defibrillator paddles in the water and fires a strong electric shock; she dies in the process but the creature is also supposedly killed. After Collins and McBride finish decompressing
column29: they leave in a mini-sub just before the reactor explodes. When they reach the surface they inflate a life raft
column30: but the creature suddenly attacks them. McBride dives into the water while Joyce stays on the raft. He spills the mini-sub's fuel and ignites it with a flare gun. The sub explodes
column31: finally killing the creature. Joyce believes that McBride is dead
column32: but he surfaces nearby
column33: having dived below the water and the exploding sub. They start rowing across the ocean
column34: waiting for a navy rescue team to arrive."

column1: 21714981;Libido;"The four segments of the film average about 30 minutes in length and are presented in the following order.The Miles Ago database of Australian films * Part 1: ""The Husband"" - Focuses on a suburban husband and wife
column2: their relationship and their sexual fantasies. * Part 2: ""The Child"" - A lonely boy seeks revenge on a man he finds engaging in intercourse with his beloved governess. * Part 3: ""The Priest"" - A priest contemplates leaving the church as a result of his indefatigable attraction to a nun. * Part 4: ""The Family Man"" - The husband of a woman in labor arranges with a friend to take two women to a secluded beach house."

column1: 11990695;Maneater;Two people disappear along the Appalachian Trail: a young man jogging with his girlfriend and a hermit who rarely leaves his home. Sheriff Grady Barnes  finds a trail in the woods which leads him to parts of the hermit's body. That night
column2: young Roy Satterly  is reading by flashlight when a Bengal tiger briefly appears in front of his bedroom window. In the morning
column3: his mother
column4: Rose
column5: finds him sleepwalking in the woods in front of their house. A cast taken at the next victim's scene points to a tiger as the hermit's killer
column6: so Sheriff Barnes holds a press conference to warn the public. The tiger visits Roy's home again that night. A tabloid paper offers a $10
column7: 000 reward for the tiger causing the town to be inundated with hunters and reporters. The sheriff forbids anyone from going in the woods and hunting the tiger
column8: but while out with Deputy Sharon Weinman
column9: he sees Roy in the woods. They give chase
column10: but instead find a dead tabloid reporter. The National Guard is called in to help. The sheriff later sees Roy in the woods again and warns him to stay out before taking him home and giving Rose the same warning. After he leaves
column11: she mistakenly believes Roy told the sheriff lies about there being a tiger and chastises him. Six National Guardsmen arrive
column12: led by Sergeant Winshiser
column13: as does Colonel James Livingston-Graham
column14: an experienced big game hunter and tracker from England who specializes in hunting man-eating tigers. Sergeant Winshiser and his men arrogantly refuse to use the sheriff's advice and help. Graham tells the sheriff the soldiers will fail due to their arrogance and that he will start his hunt for the tiger when they finish. When the guardsmen search for the tiger
column15: it kills one silently. Graham appears and explains how the tiger did it and helps them find the body. Later
column16: Deputy Weinman and Deputy Ezra Hundt
column17: the mayor's son
column18: find one of the National Guard trucks sitting empty on the road. They investigate and Weinman tells Hundt to call their position in to headquarters. She finds that the two guardsmen were attacked by the tiger
column19: one being killed and the other shot by his partner. Hearing Hundt blowing the patrol car horn
column20: she runs back to the car
column21: but the tiger has already killed him. Meanwhile
column22: Roy encounters Graham in the woods and they discuss the tiger. When Roy asks if Graham is going to kill the tiger
column23: Graham tells him that he must because it can't chose not to hunt whatever is around it
column24: including people. They shake hands and part ways with Graham continuing to the scene of the National Guard attack. When he arrives
column25: he explains how the tiger attacked the guardsmen and deputy. Later
column26: at another press conference
column27: a reporter reveals that Graham was exiled from India
column28: his former home
column29: after he failed to kill a tiger that slaughtered over 200 people. The sheriff visits Graham that night and he explains that the situation had been beyond his control. Later that night
column30: Roy dreams the tiger killed Graham and runs to his tent to check on him. Graham offers to walk him home
column31: but they end up going to the store where Rose works when Roy says she is working late. When they arrive
column32: the tiger attacks and kills her. They run into the store
column33: but are separated. Graham calls for Roy
column34: but the tiger gets into the building and attacks him
column35: Graham barely failing to kill the tiger with both shots he fires. Sheriff Barnes arrives after being alerted about a break-in alarm and is chased into the store by the tiger. He finds Graham's hat and a blood trail and tries to find him before hearing Roy calling out from under a truck outside. The sheriff dives under the truck and shields the boy as the tiger tries to attack. When the tiger jumps into the bed of the truck
column36: they run to the sheriff's truck. The sheriff shoots at the tiger
column37: but hits a gasoline tank causing it to explode and kill the tiger. Graham appears beside the building
column38: bloody but alive. Deciding his hunting days are over
column39: Graham returns home. Sheriff Barnes and his wife adopt the orphaned Roy.

column1: 3649186;Una mujer sin amor;The film opens in Mexico
column2: in the home of an upper-class antiques salesman named Don Carlos Montero and his wife Rosario
column3: whose son
column4: Carlos or Carlitos
column5: is accused of stealing by the principal of his school. Carlitos is scolded harshly by his father when he comes home
column6: and is locked in his room. Carlitos runs away
column7: but is found by an engineer named Julio Mistral who works in the forest. Julio returns the boy to his parents
column8: and Don Carlos is very grateful. Julio becomes great friends with the Montero family
column9: but in private asks Rosario why she really married such a harsh mannered and older man. One day
column10: Rosario and Carlitos pay a visit to Julio in the forest
column11: while Don Carlos spends the day in town on business. Carlitos enjoys himself immensely
column12: fishing for trout. Rosario and Julio converse privately
column13: and Julio notes how unhappy she is. Rosario reveals that she is unhappy because she married Don Carlos for his money when she was very young. Julio sympathizes her plight as a woman who has never truly loved
column14: and they fall in love with each other. Rosario and Julio begin an affair
column15: and Julio tries to convince her to run away with him to Brazil. She eventually agrees
column16: but decides to wait
column17: after Don Carlos suffers a severe heart attack. Don Carlos ultimately lives
column18: and Rosario refuses to go with Julio
column19: unable to separate Carlitos from his father
column20: who had grown close since his illness. The film skips about 20 years into the future
column21: where Carlos
column22: and his younger brother
column23: Miguel
column24: have graduated from medical school. One day
column25: news arrives that Julio Mistral has died and decided to will all of his money to Miguel. Initially
column26: everybody is perplexed at this action
column27: as Julio had never met Miguel.  Though it is not explicitly stated in the film
column28: Carlos soon pieces together that Miguel was willed this money because he is the illegitimate child of Julio and his mother
column29: Rosario. Carlos refuses Miguel's offer to share his inheritance
column30: which he uses to build a new clinic
column31: and begins acting bitter towards his mother and brother. Miguel becomes engaged to be married to a woman who Carlos is convinced wants to marry him for his money. At his wedding
column32: Don Carlos collapses and dies from a heart attack. The film comes to a conclusion as Carlos finally discloses the truth about the inheritance to Miguel
column33: who becomes very angry and fights Carlos. Rosario breaks up the fight
column34: and confirms what Carlos has said. Miguel is distraught
column35: and Rosario unapologetically tells them that Julio was the only man she ever loved. The brothers reconcile their differences at the sight of their emotional mother
column36: wrought with sadness. Carlos leaves for the tropics to do research
column37: and the film ends with Rosario placing a picture of Julio on her mantelpiece.

column1: 6935978;The Rounders;"Ben Jones  and Marion 'Howdy' Lewis  are two easygoing
column2: modern-day cowboys who make a meager living breaking wild horses. Their frequent employer is Jim Ed Love
column3: a shrewd businessman who always gets the better of them. After they bring him a string of tamed horses and spend the winter rounding up stray cows
column4: he talks them into taking a nondescript roan horse in lieu of some of their wages. Ben finds  that the horse is unrideable. Rather than turning it into soap or dog food
column5: he comes up with the bright idea of taking it to a rodeo and betting other cowhands they cannot ride it
column6: thereby doubling their earnings. Along the way
column7: the duo stop to help two none-too-bright strippers
column8: Mary  and Sister
column9: with their car
column10: which has broken down. Not knowing much about cars
column11: they give them a ride to the nearest garage
column12: but end up getting to know them better  and taking them along to the rodeo. Everything goes as planned; nobody is able to stay on the horse. Then the animal suddenly collapses and Ben spends all the money they've won for veterinary help—and a new stable to replace the one destroyed by the roan when he recovers. In the end
column13: Ben and Howdy end up right back where they started
column14: with only the roan to show for their efforts."

column1: 20903293;Maha Chor;Raju  is an orphan who is brought up by the people of colony in Juhu area of Bombay. He lives as a son of all residents of the colony and helps them for their financial needs by stealing and because of this he is jailed for some months frequently. He is affectionately called as Raju by Hindus and Khan by Muslims. Prem Singh  intends to build a hotel in the colony and compels people to vacate the place or pay Rs.10000 as rent. Actually the land belongs to Neetu the princess of Raigadh. Prem urges Neetu to marry him so that he can own the land of Juhu. But Neetu  resists the proposal. Neetu's uncle manges to get the photograph of the prince and sends it to Raj Matha. Prince Rajeshwar  is kidnapped by Prem's mother in his childhood to prevent him inherit the wealth of Raigadh palace and make her son the heir for it. Raju steals a car of Prem Singh and gets caught when he tries to sell his car to himself. Seeing his intelligent innocence he first uses him to transport smuggled stuffs to Raigadh in the car. Neetu escapes from Prem and hides at the back of the car. While Raju drives towards to Raigadh he finds her and takes her along with him. On the way
column2: though both of them but fight they develop a feeling for each other. Raju who thinks he is not eligible for the princess tries to kill his feelings.Prem recognizes the identity of lost Prince Rajeshwar in Raju. So he insists Raju to act like him in the palace but Raju refuses as he cannot serve several years of jail as his colony people need him. Prem sets fire to the colony and this angers Raju. So he sets off to palace where without any effort accepted by Queen as Prince Rajeshwar in spite of his repeated denials. Queen identifies him through his photograph
column3: burnt hand  and the finger print of prince. But astrologer who is working for Prem lies to the Queen that he is the real prince thinking Raju is the man sent by Prem. Raju was crowned as Prince Rajeshwar. The real prince is under custody of Prem's mother who is still childlike playing with toys and putting his thumb finger in his mouth like toddler. Raju captures Prem and arrests him in the palace prison. Thakur Singh who wants to be the actual heir finds that Prem is his own son. Prem reveals to his father that he is not the real prince but sent by him. Thakur Singh reveals this to all but he is not believed by anybody as he has no proof for his statement. Raju is moved by the motherly love of the queen and so he wants to leave the palace unwilling to deceive and disappoint her but stays on compulsion of Neetu as she insists Raj Mata is smiling only on his arrival. Raju swears to stay and find out the real prince. Meanwhile Queen finds out the truth and asks him to get out but is shot by Thakur Singh and blames Raju for shooting. Raju is arrested. But he escapes from them. Prem plans to kill Raju when he comes to hospital to visit Rajmata. But Raju disguises himself as Dr. Muthuswamy a man from Madras and donates the rare blood AB negative to the queen and saves her. Raju finds out the real Prince Rajeshwar who is under custody of Prem and rescues him. Prem
column4: his mother and Thakur Singh are arrested. Queen finally re-unites with her son. She also unites Neetu with Raju as Neetu actually loves him.

column1: 27387452;The Boy Who Cried Werewolf;"Jordan Sands
column2: is an allergy-prone
column3: awkward
column4: nerdy 17-year-old girl forced to be the woman of the house after her mother’s death and has often been bullied by popular girls Ashley Edwards  and Tiffany . Her embittered widower father David  is struggling to make ends meet while her younger brother Hunter  drives his family crazy with gory pranks. Their financial woes may be relieved when they inherit their Great Uncle Dragomir Ducovic’s castle in Wolfsberg
column5: Romania. After arriving in Wolfsberg during Moonlight Mania which honors the famous Wolfsberg Beast
column6: they meet the strange and steely housekeeper of the castle Madame Varcolac
column7: which strangely
column8: everytime someone utters her name
column9: a wolf is heard howling. Having spent most of her life as the Wolfsberg Manor housekeeper
column10: Madame Varcolac discourages David from selling the property
column11: but real estate agent Paulina Von Eckberg  has other plans in mind and begins dating David to win him over. The Sands’ strange visit soon goes awry when a freak lab accident in which a vial of LB-217 was broken and Jordan accidentally steps on it. After Hunter removes the vial shard from the sole of Jordan's foot
column12: Jordan starts to develop a transformation into a werewolf
column13: signs such as the desire to eat meat
column14: play with dogs
column15: and she begins growing fur that continuously regrows even after waxing & her getting new irises that are lighter blue as wolf eyes. Hunter's paranormal expert friends claim Jordan has to be a werewolf and explain that Jordan had 3 ways: Having a bloodline werewolf
column16: getting bitten or being infected by werewolf blood & they explain that LB-217 was an old Latin term for werewolf blood by the ancient Greek king
column17: Lycaon
column18: who caused the lycanthropy myth. Succumbing to the changes
column19: Jordan becomes graceful
column20: athletic
column21: and self-confident as well as being able to see without her glasses. Jordan's dark side is dangerous to others and the change befuddles her new suitor Goran
column22: the town’s young attractive butcher. Her first transformation occurred after her date with Goran where she almost attacks Hunter before David comes home causing her to retreat into the woods
column23: which Hunter becomes aware of a foreshock before the transformation
column24: seeing Jordan's wolf eyes. In order to salvage her crush and return back to her normal self
column25: Jordan must rely on Hunter to save her before it is too late. Hunter's occult-expert friends say that if Jordan stays a werewolf throughout a full moon night
column26: she will remain living as a human who will transform into a werewolf & back for the rest of her entire life. The only way to lift the curse is to kill Jordan with a silver bullet
column27: which Hunter refuses to carry out. As Hunter tries to find a way to reverse Jordan's curse
column28: he stumbles onto Varcolac
column29: who reveals to Hunter that she knows of Jordan's curse
column30: and has once lived with a cursed being herself: Uncle Dragomir. She reveals to Hunter and Jordan that their Uncle Dragomir was the Wolfsberg Beast
column31: a kind and gentle man who was a brilliant scientist and humanitarian; he researched a way to reverse the werewolf curse so that others wouldn't be forced to live the same cruel fate he had. He led an army of werewolves into a war many years ago when a clan of evil vampires attempted to rule the world; the werewolves took the victory and the Wolfsberg country became sacred land where the Wolfsberg Manor now stands. With Dragomir dead
column32: Varcolac fears that the vampires will try to rule the world by killing Jordan. Jordan offers to have her become the new Wolfsberg Beast to protect the castle
column33: but Varcolac says that only a blood-line werewolf can become the protector. The three of them go into town collecting supplies for the werewolf cure. As it turns out

column35: Hunter and David
column36: attempting to kill Jordan with a silver bullet. Hunter
column37: desperate to save everyone
column38: sights the full moon and begins stages of the transformation Jordan experienced for a few days in only a matter of seconds & becomes a werewolf . Hunter and Paulina battle for a while
column39: Hunter calls Jordan by howling & Jordan returns to fight while Varcolac continues to finish the cure & notices the rising sun. Jordan & Hunter become aware of this & finally manage to vaporize the vampires by pushing them into the lights. Jordan saves Hunter from a blow by tackling Paulina & putting her into the sunlight. Everyone returns to Wolfsberg Manor and Varcolac cures Jordan of her werewolf curse minutes before the effects would become permanent. The lawyer in charge of Dragomir's estate allows Varcolac to continue working there
column40: and gives the Sands the money they inherited from Dragomir . Hunter becomes the Wolfsberg Beast to take Dragomir's place
column41: howling in werewolf form from a mountain outside the town during the Wolfsberg festival that honors him. The family returns to the U.S. where Jordan returns to school
column42: more secure and confident
column43: with a new fashion sense and worshiped by Tiffany and Ashley and dates Goran
column44: who transferred to the school. David has also begun dating again having made sure that he has seen his latest date in the day. Unbeknownst to the Sands family
column45: Paulina was not killed

column47: and moves in as the Sands' neighbor in the final scene. Before the credits roll
column48: the characters of the film are seen doing a karaoke of the song ""Baby One More Time."""

column1: 235406;Mother India;"The film begins with construction completion of a water canal to the village

column3: as the 'mother' of the village

column19: especially Sukhilala's daughter. Ramu
column20: by contrast

column1: 7718873;Mosquito Man;Dr. Jennifer Allen  in Baltimore
column2: Maryland wants to find a cure for a disease known as the Gillian virus
column3: a disease similar yet more deadly than the West Nile virus. She and a colleague capture infected mosquitoes and give them small doses of radiation. She explains that the levels have to be exact because if the mosquitoes receive too much radiation
column4: the results could be more devastating than the virus itself. A convict named Ray  joins Dr. Allen's program in exchange for his lifelong prison sentence. He takes a hostage and convinces Dr. Allen to open the door to the experiment room. The security guards open fire and cause an explosion that showers Ray and Dr. Allen with the chemicals and the genetically altered mosquitoes. Ray manages to flee the scene. He begins to transform into the titular monster
column5: a deformed chimera of himself and a mosquito
column6: yet he manages to find his way to his ex girlfriend's apartment
column7: where the process continues. When the ex comes home
column8: she finds it in ruins. She and Ray have a short
column9: anxious conversation before Ray's transformation is complete and he kills her. Meanwhile Dr. Allen returns home with her boyfriend
column10: Lt. Tom Randall . That evening
column11: she notices her wrist is red and raw-looking. She thinks little of it
column12: but next morning
column13: it has spread to her entire arm. Later
column14: while kissing Tom
column15: she has a sudden craving for blood and bites him. He is called to Ray's girlfriend apartment and leaves. Dr. Allen rushes into the bathroom to find her arm bleeding. She convulses
column16: falls to the floor and her skin starts to bubble. Tom arrives at the crime scene and is puzzled by the way Ray's girlfriend died. He is called to investigate another crime scene
column17: where he encounters Mansquito. The monster seems unstoppable
column18: until Tom shocks him with a stun gun
column19: making him flee in pain. Tom's partner doesn't believe him at first but puts a bulletin out on the creature. At the research station
column20: Dr. Allen discovers she is also changing into a human-mosquito hybrid
column21: but more slowly as she received a smaller dose than Ray. Mansquito appears but doesn't try to kill her
column22: and after she faints
column23: the monster leaves. Tom takes her to the hospital. The doctor wants to give Dr. Allen a blood transfusion to slow down the transformation
column24: but she replies that nothing can stop the mutation. She believes the monster sensed that she is turning into a creature like him and that once the transformation is complete
column25: he will want to mate with her. Outside
column26: a guard falls victim to the monster and Tom leaves to investigate. Mansquito undergoes another transformation
column27: this time growing wings. Dr. Allen also undergoes another transformation and alerts the officers of Mansquito's arrival. They fail to stop him. The monster heads for Dr. Allen
column28: but she manages to escape. Tom fires a rocket launcher at the oxygen tanks behind Mansquito and assumes the creature was killed by the explosion
column29: but that is not the case. Meanwhile
column30: back at the lab
column31: Dr. Allen undergoes yet another transformation and releases the last batch of genetically altered mosquitoes
column32: which have been perfected. Tom arrives and Dr. Allen tells him that Mansquito is still alive. She tries to commit suicide by stabbing herself with a syringe
column33: because without a mate
column34: Mansquito will die. The monster arrives and Tom fights him to no avail. Dr. Allen is seriously injured by Mansquito
column35: who is now focused on killing her rather than mating with her. Tom uses the stun gun and once again
column36: it works. Seeing this
column37: Dr. Allen breaks an electrical line and electrocutes Mansquito and herself to death. Tom writes a report about the incident and the Gillian virus is wiped out by the altered mosquitoes.

column1: 142423;Il Postino;"Pablo Neruda
column2: the famous Chilean poet and communist
column3: is exiled to a small island in Italy for political reasons. His wife accompanies him. On the island
column4: local Mario Ruoppolo is dissatisfied with being a fisherman like his father. Mario looks for other work and is hired as a temporary postman with Neruda as his only customer. To get the job
column5: he must declare himself a communist to keep the postmaster happy. He uses his bicycle to hand deliver Neruda's mail. Though poorly educated
column6: the postman eventually befriends Neruda and becomes further influenced by Neruda's political views and poetry. Meanwhile
column7: Mario falls in love with a beautiful young lady
column8: Beatrice Russo
column9: who works in her aunt's village cafe. He is shy with her
column10: but he enlists Neruda's help. Mario constantly asks Neruda if particular metaphors he uses are suitable for his poems. Mario is able to better communicate with Beatrice and express his love through poetry. Despite the aunt's strong disapproval of Mario

column1: 29551629;Tradition is a Temple;Contemporary New Orleans jazz musicians discuss their childhood introductions to music in Baptist churches and through local traditions like second line and Jazz Funerals

column3: director Darren Hoffman explores the potential “death” of traditional jazz through modernization and marginalization and its preservation through mentorship and the continuation of traditions that intrigue and inspire young people to play the music of previous generations.

He blames the doctor for the medication driving her off the edge and refuses the doctor's recommendation for shock therapy. His frustration with Betty's condition and the doctors cause him to assault the doctor and get kicked out of the hospital. He then gets news that someone wants to publish his book. He later returns incognito to visit Betty. She is totally unaware of the world around her. Still Zorg whispers into her ear his feelings and swears to tell their story. Zorg
column32: out of love and pity

Betty's free spirited nature and devotion to Zorg develop into alarming obsession

column1: 24268011;Phir Kabhi;Phir Kabhi targets the heart of its audience. It is all about emotions. It is a sensitive tale of Love . There are many moments in the film where one may realize the meaning behind the saying
column2: crying while laughing and laughing also while crying. How both the phenomena happen together can be witnessed via few moments of this film. Film rides over the successive sequences of light and sensitive scenes. At one moment something light
column3: humorous and lively is happening on screen and a smile is flowing on the lips of the characters and audiences also and all of a sudden it’s followed by a very intense and sensitive sequence and not only characters pass through sad moments but audiences may also feel the impact of those onscreen happenings. Those who want to see one of the best performances of Mithun Chakraborty
column4: may watch the film for that purpose. New actors may learn from his performance
column5: how to cover a vast range of emotions while playing a character. Light and camera departments have performed very well. Sound  though hears loud at some places. Students of cinematography may watch the film for very good work performed by Nataraja Subramanian. Cinematography is fascinating. One very attractive scene
column6: he has captured
column7: is where Mithun and Tinnu Anand are shown standing at sea shore Film swings between present
column8: memories of the past and dreams of future and editor
column9: Mahesh Narayan
column10: has driven the vehicle of this mixing in such a smooth manner that eyes and attention of an audience may not even realize that a gear has been changed. A kind of perfection is there. This is not just another love story of senior citizens. It has its own merits. Story may look familiar but expansion of the story through the events is interesting. A couple lives a married life together for 40–50 years and then one dies and leaves other to spend rest of the years of his/her life alone. One becomes habitual of other’s presence in every single minute of the life and all of a sudden that person is not here. Person has gone but other person’s dependency on him/her has not been vanished. How to handle this loneliness? “Death is quite an honest enemy
column11: it does not accept friendship. It kills but it kills for once and all. Loneliness is a fastidious enemy. One extends the hands of friendship towards it and it becomes more strangely stern in attitude. It kills one all the time again and again. It kills at home
column12: at market place and it does not spare one at temples also. At an old age it becomes difficult to fight with the loneliness. An old train moves slowly and it follows the discipline of go-stop-go. It stops at such stations also where if one looks outside the window then he finds silence all over. If he gets a signal to go ahead a person goes ahead. “ Mithun says abovementioned monologue before the mirror in his bedroom and film is based upon the meaning of this monologue. Mithun will simply move the audience in the scene where he gets up early in the morning and finds a cigarette kept by his wife
column13: Rati Agnihotri
column14: on the side table of his bed. He leaves the bed
column15: picks up the cigarette and calls for his wife. He is very happy. He is overwhelmed by the loving care which his wife showers upon him. He wants to share this happiness with his wife. Everything is bringing a smile to the audience but after a few seconds only whole atmosphere is changed into a gloomy one and Mithun had to create two exactly opposite atmospheres and he does this job very effectively. A terrific performance he has given in these moments and throughout the film he remains the main source from whom this film gets its maximum strength. He has created many very good moments in the film. Another remarkable scene is where he is searching his watch and he forgets that Rati is dead now and cries upon realizing it. His grand daughter comes there and he conceals his tears from her. Another gem of a scene is where he tells Kitu Gidvani that he will not meet or write Dimple ever. Plot takes some inspiration from the mythological tale of Radha and Krishna. In short
column16: Mithun’s first love is Dimple but situations separate them in school time only. Later he marries Rati and after her death only he again comes in contact with Dimple. Two old lovers
column17: who are suffering from loneliness
column18: try to search solace in each others company which is not initially acceptable to Mithun’s daughter in law. An entire new generation remains devoid of the pleasure of writing and reading the letters and this film at least shows the use of this old and now obsolete but very good communication method. Feelings may be conveyed by the email also but to read something in sender’s own hand writing certainly enhances the impact of the words. Words carry more emotions through hand written letters than email or printed greeting cards. Dimple Kapadia adequately supports the film. So do Gulshan Grover and Kittu Gidvani. Tinnu Anand

column1: 770277;Indochine;"At the outset of the film
column2: Camille
column3: a young girl from the Nguyen Dynasty
column4: is adopted by Éliane Devries after her parents die in a plane crash at the end of the 1910s. Madame Devries owns and operates a large rubber plantation in Indochina that employs many indentured laborers. Unmarried
column5: she raises Camille as her own daughter. Madame Devries meets and has a fleeting affair with a younger man
column6: Jean-Baptiste Le Guen
column7: a lieutenant in the French Navy. When Camille is sixteen
column8: a French police officer shoots a Vietnamese prisoner who is escaping through the city streets. Camille and her classmates had been walking nearby
column9: and just as the prisoner is about to be shot he runs past Camille. The prisoner then falls dead onto Camille
column10: knocking her unconscious and covering her with his blood. Jean-Baptiste finds Camille
column11: brings her to safety
column12: and cleans off the blood—cutting off her dress in the process and exposing her bosom. Camille awakens in Jean-Baptiste's arms and immediately falls in love with him. Apparently through her connections with high-ranking officials in the navy
column13: Madame Devries has Jean-Baptiste transferred to Haiphong to protect Camille from being hurt. Jean-Baptiste confronts Madame Devries about this at a Christmas party celebration at her place
column14: and a loud spat ensues. As a result of his misbehavior
column15: instead of being transferred to Haiphong
column16: Jean-Baptiste is sent to a remote French military base in the north of Vietnam
column17: on the notorious Dragon Island. Against her better judgment
column18: Madame Devries allows Camille to become engaged to Tanh
column19: a young man who has studied in France and supports the Communists  in 1930. The marriage is arranged by Tanh's wealthy
column20: merchant mother. The day after the engagement
column21: Tanh allows Camille to leave and look for Jean-Baptiste up north. Camille travels with a Vietnamese family

column23: but they are killed by a French naval officer. When Jean-Baptiste arrives on the scene and demands that the officer tell him what happened
column24: the officer says that the family refused to be split up
column25: and started inciting a riot by yelling communist slogans. Jean-Baptiste sees Camille among the laborers and starts to lead her away. However
column26: upon seeing her traveling companions dead
column27: Camille attacks the French officer and then shoots him with his own gun. Camille and Jean-Baptiste escape from the island and sail away through the Gulf of Tonkin for many days without food or water. Eventually
column28: they come ashore and are rescued by a Communist theater troupe. The troupe takes them to a hidden valley where they are hidden in a large complex of buildings. Eventually
column29: they must leave the valley because the Communists have other
column30: more important people to hide. Tanh
column31: now a high-ranking Communist operative

Guy arranges for French agents to look for Camille and Jean-Baptiste in the North. They look up and down the Gulf of Tonkin but with no success. Eventually
column34: Guy realizes that traveling theater troupes may be behind many near-simultaneous insurrections in the north. He orders all theater troupes traveling in certain northern routes to be arrested. One morning

column37: and escape with the theater troupe. French authorities give Étienne to Madame Devries. Jean-Baptiste spends time in prison and does not speak with anyone. Eventually

column1: 24073089;Folks!;"Folks! tells the story of Jon Aldrich
column2: a successful stockbroker who is living the good life with a wife and kids until his aging father with dementia accidentally burns down his own house. Jon tries to get his sister
column3: Arlene Aldrich  who has two sons of her own but is an irresponsible gold digger
column4: but she won't even open the door. As a result his father Harry Aldrich/Pop  and his mother Mildred Alrdich  have to move in with him and his family. That is the moment that his good life starts going down hill. The company he works for was apparently doing illegal things which Jon knew nothing of

column6: his wife Audrey  thinks moves out with the kids
column7: and they lose all their furniture and belongs except their apartment. Harry continues to unintentionally injure Jon
column8: causing him hearing lost
column9: a broken hand
column10: a car runs over his foot
column11: and he manages to lose a testicle. Jon slowly starts to lose his own sanity
column12: but in a brief moment of his own sanity Harry tells Jon that he never wanted to be a burden on him but he soon slips back into his state of dementia

column14: and they want Jon to help them die so he can collect the insurance money. Jon is totally against this at first but after a while he changes his tune. Jon refuses at first due to the fact that she would not even open the door for them but he eventually caves in and lets them stay. Arlene also joins in on the attempts to help their parents die
column15: hoping for a cut of the insurance money. Though her attempts are also unsuccessful. Things slowly start looking up for Jon as Audrey eventually shows up home to tell John she was wrong for leaving and how much she loves the fact that he was willing to take in both of his parents. Upon her arrival she realizes all all the injuries Jon has suffered since she saw him last
column16: including the missing testicle. As they are reconciling Jon realizes that Arlene and his parents are gone and he knows they are going to try to commit suicide again with the help of his sister
column17: so he tracks them down in an attempt to stop them which he successfully does
column18: but not without facing a bit more injury. Alrdich eventually get their lives on track. Jon and Audrey buy a house and Jon's parents live with them. Arlene is now with a man who knows how to handle her bad behaving children. At the end we finally find out that Harry hasn't been yelling McDonalds because he was hungry
column19: he was yelling it because he bought stock in McDonnell Douglas years and years ago
column20: meaning he is worth tons of money."

column1: 30405742;Plug & Pray;Computer experts around the world strive towards the development of intelligent robots. Pioneers like Raymond Kurzweil and Hiroshi Ishiguro dream of fashioning intelligent machines that will equal their human creators. In this potential reality
column2: man and machine merge as a single unity. Rejecting evolution's biological shackles tantalisingly dangles the promise of eternal life for those bold enough to seize it. But others
column3: like Joseph Weizenbaum
column4: counter attack against society's limitless faith in the redemptive powers of technology. Eloquent and tactful
column5: he questions the prevailing discourses on new technologies
column6: and their ethical relationships to human life. The film delves into a world where computer technology
column7: robotics
column8: biology
column9: neuroscience
column10: and developmental psychology merge and features the world’s leading roboticists in their laboratories in Japan
column11: the USA
column12: Italy and Germany.
